A regulation stipulating the amount of U.S. tobacco in American-made cigarettes gives tobacco farmers and Philip Morris a big lift. But it could raise costs for some cigarette manufacturers and further complicate troubled world trade talks. [ Page A1. ]

The Economy

A regulation stipulating the amount of U.S. tobacco in American-made cigarettes gives tobacco farmers and Philip Morris a big lift. But it could raise costs for some cigarette manufacturers and further complicate troubled world trade talks. [ Page A1. ]
Resolution Trust reached a $45 million settlement with Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison over the law firm's role in junk bond investments that helped the Centrust savings and loan. [ D1. ]
Consumers were only slightly more optimistic about the economy this month, the Conference Board reported. [ D12. ] The Media Business

The Supreme Court agreed to rule on the constitutionality of a 1992 law that requires cable television operators to devote part of their channel capacity to local broadcast stations. The case was filed by Turner Broadcasting and other cable operators. [ A17. ]
Republicans in Congress are accusing Democrats of causing higher cable television rates through a law that was intended to bring rates down. [ D1. ]
The 15 members of the Paramount board have become acutely aware of the risks and responsibilities they face as they weigh rival buyout offers. [ D4. ]

The New York Post teetered on the edge of extinction, as Rupert Murdoch pulled out of an agreement to buy the paper after a strike by the Newspaper Guild and the refusal of production workers to cross the picket line. [ A1. ]
Shareholders of The New York Times Company and the parent of The Boston Globe approved a $1 billion merger. [ D5. ] International
Approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement may rely on Mexico's vague pledge to increase its minimum wage. [ A1. ]
Pillsbury is setting up a joint venture with a leading South African food company, moving quickly after Nelson Mandela's call for an end to trade sanctions against that country. [ D1. ]
Gianni Agnelli will postpone his retirement from the troubled Italian auto maker Fiat. [ D1. ] Companies
Washington is giving Detroit weapons technology, and the Big Three auto makers will try to build a more efficient car. [ D1. ]
G.M. is selling 80 percent of its $760 million parts operation to ITT for $400 million. [ D3. ] Business Technology
When the F.C.C. recently announced rules for a new generation of wireless communications, it left unanswered many questions about technical pitfalls and regulatory issues. [ D5. ]
The Cartoon Network is introducing what it calls the first "live animation" cartoon -- the latest union of high tech and Hollywood. [ D5. ] Markets
California sold $800 million of bonds, benefiting from the hunger for yields in an environment of low rates. [ D16. ]
Stocks were mixed in a lackluster session. The Dow lost 1.68 points, to close at 3,566.02. [ D6. ]
The dollar fell versus the yen and other currencies. [ D18. ] Crude oil prices continued to rise. [ D18 ] Today's Columns
